item.title: World’s First Treaty to Protect the High Seas Becomes Law
item.description: Over two decades after negotiations began, the High Seas Treaty is designed to protect biodiversity in international waters by enabling conservation zones.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:credit: Jakub Gojda/Alamy
item.media:description: The High Seas Treaty represents the first time that the vast majority of international waters, which lie outside of any country’s jurisdiction and cover nearly half the globe, can be protected.

item.title: How Wall Street Turned Its Back on Climate Change
item.description: Six years after the financial industry pledged to use trillions to fight climate change and reshape finance, its efforts have largely collapsed.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Climate activists protest BlackRock in New York City in 2023.

item.title: The $2 Rental Batteries Helping to Power South Africa
item.description: The batteries offer an affordable system for those who lack reliable power and the money to buy their own solar panels.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Anselmo Mugabe, in stripy shirt, who runs a hair Salon in Thembisa, a township north east of Johannesburg, uses the BPowerD batteries in order to run his business.

item.title: Edison Files Claims Against Los Angeles County and Others on Eaton Fire
item.description: Southern California Edison said its equipment most likely started the Eaton fire but asserted that government agencies and other businesses shared liability for the devastation.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Eaton fire killed 19 people and destroyed more than 9,400 buildings in Southern California.

item.title: Supreme Court to Decide if the Pesticide Roundup Is Shielded From Lawsuits
item.description: The case could affect thousands of claims that the widely used weedkiller causes cancer.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Goss Images, via Alamy
item.media:description: Roundup, used widely on cropland, has faced controversy over its effects on human health.

item.title: Virginia Coastal Offshore Wind Project Can Continue, Judge Rules
item.description: Construction can continue on an $11.2 billion project off the coast of Virginia, said to be 70 percent complete.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Wind turbine components at a staging area for the Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind project in Portsmouth, Va., last month.

item.title: Trump and States Aim to Stop A.I. From Inflating Energy Bills
item.description: Demand from centers that power artificial intelligence has driven up electricity bills, frustrating consumers.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nationwide spike in electricity costs is being driven by the construction of data centers that power artificial intelligence.

item.title: Trump Wants to Halt Almost All Coal Plant Shutdowns. It Could Get Messy.
item.description: Even as administration officials vowed this week to head off scheduled retirements, some aging plants are now breaking, and costs could run to the billions.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Brittany Peterson/Associated Press
item.media:description: A coal-burning unit at the Craig Generating Station had been set to close since 2016, but the Energy Department has ordered that it stay open.

item.title: State and Federal Lawmakers Want Data Centers to Pay More for Energy
item.description: Despite many proposals, there is little consensus among governors, lawmakers and tech executives about exactly how much the companies behind data centers should pay for electricity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Scott Ball for The New York Times
item.media:description: A data center built by OpenAI and Oracle in Abilene, Texas.

item.title: Empire Wind Project Can Resume Construction, Judge Rules
item.description: A federal judge said the Empire Wind project off Long Island would suffer “irreparable harm” if the Trump administration continued to hold up work.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Equinor, via Reuters
item.media:description: The South Brooklyn Marine Terminal, the staging site for the Empire Wind offshore wind project.

item.title: How One Company, Neptune Flood, Is Pushing a Private Takeover of Flood Insurance
item.description: For half a century, a federal program has covered most at-risk properties. Now, a private company is pitching a plan to shrink the government’s role.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Mike Belleme for The New York Times
item.media:description: A home in Swannanoa, N.C., that was damaged by flooding from Hurricane Helene in 2024.

item.title: U.S. Refiners to Profit as Trump Asserts Control Over Venezuelan Oil
item.description: The companies that turn oil into gasoline and diesel are likely to benefit more, right away, than the businesses that pump oil out of the ground.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Valero Energy refinery in Houston. U.S. refining companies are poised to profit if more Venezuelan oil starts flowing to the United States.

item.title: Extreme Weather Events Hit Around the World in 2025
item.description: Last year was Earth’s third hottest globally, but temperature is just one measure of climate change’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Palisades Fire burning along the Pacific Coast Highway early last January.

item.title: The View From Above Antarctica’s Fastest Melting Glacier
item.description: Times journalists were able to get tantalizingly close to the Thwaites glacier, which scientists are hoping to spend weeks studying up close.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The icebreaker Araon at the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica on Sunday.

item.title: E.P.A. Moves to Limit States’ Ability to Block Pipelines
item.description: The agency wants to curtail a section of the Clean Water Act that Democratic governors have used to restrict fossil fuel development.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas pipeline under construction near Amarillo, Texas, in November.

item.title: U.S. Emissions Jumped in 2025 as Coal Power Rebounded
item.description: The increase in planet-warming emissions came after two years of decline as demand for electricity has been surging.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Charlie Riedel/Associated Press
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant near Emmett, Kan. Demand for power has started surging in recent years amid a boom in data centers, an upswing of domestic manufacturing and the spread of electric vehicles.

item.title: Trump Cuts to Energy Projects in Blue States Were Unlawful, Judge Rules
item.description: The Energy Department canceled $7.5 billion in Biden-era energy spending, largely in Democratic-led states, during last year’s government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The cuts were part of a larger effort by the Energy Department to cancel spending for projects like hydrogen fuel hubs, electrical grid upgrades and efforts to reduce methane leaks.

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Effort to Stop Rhode Island’s Revolution Wind Project
item.description: The ruling means that construction can continue on Revolution Wind, a $6.2 billion project off the coast of Rhode Island, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Components of the Revolution Wind farm project on a pier in New London, Conn., in September.

item.title: Supreme Court Grapples With Louisiana Coastal Lawsuits Against Oil Companies
item.description: The justices heard arguments over whether oil companies sued by Louisiana could move the cases from state to federal court, a venue thought to be friendlier to corporate interests.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Chevron Oronite oil additives manufacturing facility, seen in 2008 in Plaquemines Parish, La.

item.title: Under Trump, U.S. Adds Fuel to a Heating Planet
item.description: The president’s embrace of fossil fuels and withdrawal from the global fight against climate change will make it hard to keep warming at safe levels, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: America’s greenhouse gas emissions from the burning of coal, oil and gas, which had finally started to decline, rose 1.9 percent after Mr. Trump returned to office.

item.title: Is Grass-Fed Beef Better?
item.description: The idea of cows grazing in a pasture seems idyllic. We asked experts how their emissions stack up compared to factory farms.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Photo by Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Louisiana’s Eroding Coast
item.description: Local governments are suing oil companies over environmental damage. The companies want the suits moved out of state courts, to friendlier venues.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil industry infrastructure near Pointe à la Hache in Plaquemines Parish, La.
